p: Influenza viruses cause severe respiratory illness, leading to 290,000â€“650,000 deaths annually worldwide as estimated by the World Health Organization (WHO) [ 1]. Influenza viruses consist of four known genera, A, B, C, and D, which belong to the family Orthomyxoviridae [ 2]. Of these four genera, influenza A virus causes the greatest mortality and is the most common cause of both seasonal and pandemic influenza outbreaks. Influenza B virus can cause seasonal influenza while the influenza C virus can infect children with mild respiratory symptoms. Little is known about the impact of recently discovered influenza D virus on human health [ 3, 4].
